H0.text: Decomposers break down dead organisms and other organic waste and release inorganic molecules back to the environment.

H1.text: Detritivores are organisms that break down dead organisms and other organic waste, releasing inorganic molecules back into the environment.

H2.text: Nematodes are organisms that break down dead organisms and other organic waste and release inorganic molecules back to the environment.

H3.text: Carnivores are organisms that break down dead organisms and other organic waste and release inorganic molecules back to the environment.

A4.text: Decomposers are organisms that break down dead organisms and release the nutrients from the dead matter into the environment around them.

A5.text: Invertebrates such as earthworms, woodlice, and sea cucumbers that digest dead matter internally and release nutrients locally via their feces.

A6.text: Detritivores are heterotrophs that obtain nutrients by consuming detritus (decomposing plant and animal parts as well as feces).

A7.text: Detritivores perform the first stage of remineralization by fragmenting the dead plant matter, allowing decomposers to perform the second stage of remineralization.
